articles.headline: Drug Giant Faced a Reckoning as China Took Aim at Bribery
articles.snippet: China sought to make an example of GlaxoSmithKline in a case that involved bribery of doctors and investigators and ended with guilty pleas and record penalties.
articles.abstract: China sought to make an example of GlaxoSmithKline in a case that involved bribery of doctors and investigators and ended with guilty pleas and record penalties.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Peter Humphrey was in the bathroom of his Shanghai apartment when the police kicked the door off its hinges and knocked him to the ground. Nearly two dozen officers stormed his home. They confiscated files, laptops and hard drives related to his work as a corporate investigator.

articles.headline: Black Turnout Soft in Early Voting, Boding Ill for Hillary Clinton
articles.snippet: The numbers in several states have begun pointing to a slump many Democrats feared might materialize without the nation’s first black president on the ticket.
articles.abstract: The numbers in several states have begun pointing to a slump many Democrats feared might materialize without the nation’s first black president on the ticket.
articles.lead_paragraph: African-Americans are failing to vote at the robust levels they did four years ago in several states that could help decide the presidential election, creating a vexing problem for Hillary Clinton as she clings to a deteriorating lead over Donald J. Trump with Election Day just a week away.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters, Richard Fausset and Michael Wines

articles.headline: F.B.I.’s Email Disclosure Broke a Pattern Followed Even This Summer
articles.snippet: At the Justice Department’s urging, the F.B.I. did not actively pursue cases on the Clinton Foundation and a former Trump campaign chairman so close to the election.
articles.abstract: At the Justice Department’s urging, the F.B.I. did not actively pursue cases on the Clinton Foundation and a former Trump campaign chairman so close to the election.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. and Justice Department faced a hard decision in two investigations this past summer that had the potential to rock the presidential election. The first case involved Donald J. Trump’s campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, and secretive business dealings in Ukraine. The second focused on Hillary Clinton’s relationships with donors to her family foundation.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Michael S. Schmidt, Adam Goldman and William K. Rashbaum

articles.headline: The Secret Lives of Hotel Doormen
articles.snippet: Technology can seem a plague to the many service workers it displaces. But one hotel doorman knows there are things an app cannot do — things that make him indispensable.
articles.abstract: Technology can seem a plague to the many service workers it displaces. But one hotel doorman knows there are things an app cannot do — things that make him indispensable.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — If the entrance of a hotel is its own sort of stage, then few actors have commanded one quite like Gary Sykes, head doorman at the Thompson Chicago.

articles.headline: How the Internet Is Loosening Our Grip on the Truth
articles.snippet: A wider variety of news sources was supposed to be the bulwark of a rational age. Instead, we are roiled by biases, gorging on what confirms our ideas and shunning what does not.
articles.abstract: A wider variety of news sources was supposed to be the bulwark of a rational age. Instead, we are roiled by biases, gorging on what confirms our ideas and shunning what does not.
articles.lead_paragraph: Next week, if all goes well, someone will win the presidency. What happens after that is anyone’s guess. Will the losing side believe the results? Will the bulk of Americans recognize the legitimacy of the new president? And will we all be able to clean up the piles of lies, hoaxes and other dung that have been hurled so freely in this hyper-charged, fact-free election?

articles.headline: Trump, Waking a ‘Sleeping Giant,’ Helps Clinton Build an Unlikely Firewall
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump’s alienation of key voting blocs has bolstered Democrats in the West and South, and Republicans fear it could be a grim glimpse of their future.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump’s alienation of key voting blocs has bolstered Democrats in the West and South, and Republicans fear it could be a grim glimpse of their future.
articles.lead_paragraph: CASA GRANDE, Ariz. — Since moving to Arizona 15 years ago, Nieves Lorenzo watched as Hispanics grew in numbers but only haltingly asserted themselves as a political force. Then came Donald J. Trump’s presidential candidacy.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Farmers’ Unchecked Crop Burning Fuels India’s Air Pollution
articles.snippet: The burning of straw is a major contributor to New Delhi’s winter air pollution, and it could be stopped if the government got serious.
articles.abstract: The burning of straw is a major contributor to New Delhi’s winter air pollution, and it could be stopped if the government got serious.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAULVIWALA, India — Desperate to reduce the pollution that has made New Delhi’s air quality among the worst in the world, the city has banned private cars for two-week periods and campaigned to reduce its ubiquitous fireworks during holiday celebrations.

articles.headline: Nonprofit Employees, Already Underpaid, Face Special Challenges in Retirement
articles.snippet: Short on time and money, small nonprofits often have little of either left for researching and adopting the best savings vehicles for their workers.
articles.abstract: Short on time and money, small nonprofits often have little of either left for researching and adopting the best savings vehicles for their workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are untold numbers of crusading Roman Catholics in the annals of world history, but there probably has never been one quite like Mary Brunson.

articles.headline: Veterans, Feeling Abandoned, Stand by Donald Trump
articles.snippet: Many who served in Iraq and Afghanistan are proud of their service but exhausted by its burdens, and they distrust the political class that reshaped their lives.
articles.abstract: Many who served in Iraq and Afghanistan are proud of their service but exhausted by its burdens, and they distrust the political class that reshaped their lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: The roster of retired military officers endorsing Hillary Clinton in September glittered with decoration and rank. One former general led the American surge in Anbar, one of the most violent provinces in Iraq. Another commanded American-led allied forces battling the Taliban in Afghanistan. Yet another trained the first Iraqis to combat Islamic insurgents in their own country.
